Comment: Since you have closed primaries, yes. You should always register as the party whose primary you want to vote in, unless you live in an open primary state. There's no rule, legally or informally, that says you have to vote for your affiliated party in the general election.   I always say "I'm X at heart, but Y on paper", because I'm signed up for the majority party in my state even though I have opposite beliefs. This is because the same party always gets elected, so the primary is more important than the general election here.  In some states the number of registered voters for a third party affect their presence on the ballot... but they don't have much of a chance unless you have ranked choice voting, anyway.

Comment: Read up on [Duverger's Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duverger%27s_law). Basically given how we elect people (first past the post, single representative districts) you are going to have 2 parties that matter and small parties that affect nothing. If the Greens  every have a position that represents a significant portion of the electorate one of the other parties will adopt that position.  The only voting Green can do is help the party *furthest* from your views. Registering Democrat gives you some influence on which Democrat runs.

Comment: Yes, it absolutely makes a difference. It makes it so your voice isn't heard and you are not considered part of the bargaining table. Because the US uses a single-member district plurality voting system (also called "First Past the Post by people whose political education consists solely of YouTube Videos), voting coalitions are formed prior to elections rather than afterward like other liberal democracies. Third parties in places like the US are voluntarily abstaining from the democratic process in the vain hope that one day their party will be the big one.

Comment: It should be noted that you very much can help elect the Dems who are nominated by their party. Sanders has never earned a broader national nomination, so no one can help get him elected beyond his current position.  But if you're talking about the primary, then yes, if you want to help the Dems govern who they think should be the future of their party, then you would need to be at least nominally committed to the Dems. That's just how it is.  For what it's worth, the Green party isn't really a functional political party. They don't run local or congressional candidates and do not make any effort to build up a grassroots coalition of voters that can actually win races. Even if we just completely ignored how elections work and assumed Jill Stein *somehow* could win the presidency, she'd still accomplish zero percent of her platform because she would have no organized political structure in Congress or anywhere else to enact that platform.  Really, if you want to have any usefulness on the American political system at all, you should register with an actual political party like the Dems or Reps. These parties are big and popular for a reason. They are actual functional political parties that both have the agency to make and keep promises and also allow their voters to have meaningful participation in our political system.  But remember, at the end of the day, having only very limited ability for any individual to influence the outcomes is the express point. The whole reason we like representative democracy is *because* you can't simply choose to spend more money or put in more effort to guarantee your preferred outcomes. The results of our system are determined by the actions of the collective, and our votes only have meaning when they are part of a multitude. That is a feature, not a bug.

It becomes obvious that they are trying to get a sample that fits whomever they are polling for.   More likely they've already captured a statistically representational number of X-leaning independents and are trying to round out their poll with Y-leaning independents, as opposed to it being a skewed poll.  In order for polls to be representative they need to sample/weight poll participants accurately. If they're calling in a deep blue state, for example, they may have already talked to enough left-leaning independents and are hunting for some conservative-leaning independents to get an accurate people of what they think -- because they presumably know what you think by having already talked to all your neighbors.
